title: Fuller v. Fuller
description: In this domestic appeal, Husband appeals the awards of equitable distribution, alimony, and expert fees to Wife.  He also appeals the finding that a real estate holding company was  a marital asset.  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Elaine M. Fuller, Respondent,
v.
William F. Fuller, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4150
Heard June 6, 2006 â€“ Filed September 11, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART,
REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
David Alan Wilson and Kenneth C. Porter, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â  In this domestic action, William F. Fuller (Husband) appeals the awards of equitable distribution, alimony, and expert fees to his former wife, Elaine M. Fuller (Wife).Â  Husband also appeals the finding that a real estate holding company was a marital asset.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in 1980, and two children were born of the marriage:Â  William in 1982, and Brittany in 1985.Â  When the couple first married, Wife was employed at South Carolina National Bank.Â  Later, the couple moved to Charlotte and Wife began working in a clothing boutique.Â  During this time, Husband worked at Owens Corning.Â  While Husband and Wife lived in Charlotte, they became interested in selling real estate and attended classes.Â  Upon finishing, they relocated to Greenville, where both still reside.Â  Wife continued to work in real estate until the birth of the coupleâ€™s children.Â  At that point, Wife became the party primarily responsible for caring for the children and taking care of the home.Â  The couple and their children lived an affluent lifestyle.Â  The parties had a large home in an exclusive area of Greenville, belonged to a country club, and took numerous family vacations.Â  Wife stated that she did not really think about money and bought whatever she wanted for herself and the children.Â  
Early in the marriage, Husband began to work at American Federal Bank and simultaneously began a residential construction company, Fulco Homes (Fulco).Â  Husband and Wife were each fifty percent shareholders in the company.Â  After eight years, Husband was able to pursue Fulco full-time.Â  In exchange for periodically working as a decorator and doing whatever else needed to be done for Fulco, Wife received a salary of $18,000 from Fulco.Â  Husband began Fulco with a loan from his aunt that he repaid in monthly installments with interest.Â  When Husbandâ€™s aunt died, the unpaid balance of the loan amounted to over $200,000.Â  However, Husband was the beneficiary of auntâ€™s estate, and the debt was forgiven.Â  Â 
Husband and Wife each had interests in numerous companies.Â  In 1989, Husband formed CF Enterprises, a real estate holding company, with his cousin, Ben Crumpler.Â  Wifeâ€™s father started Maxwell Family, LLC, (Maxwell Family), which owned a one-third interest in Stonehaven Subdivision Development and various other properties held just for investment purposes.Â  Wifeâ€™s father gave a fifteen point ninety-four percent interest in Maxwell Family to Wife and a five percent interest to Husband.Â  Both of these interests were gifts, and it is undisputed they are nonmarital.Â  In 2002, Wife received $74,000 from Maxwell Family and Husband received $26,000.Â  In 2003, by the time of the final hearing, Wife received $38,000 and expected to receive around $4,000 more.Â  Because the neighborhood was being â€œdeveloped out,â€ there were fewer lots remaining and eventually the income from Maxwell Family would dissipate.Â  Additionally, the partiesâ€™ company, Fulco, did most of its building in the Stonehaven Subdivision.Â  
Wife had interests in other family enterprises, including Maxwell Road Developers[1] and the Maxwell Family Trust.Â  Wifeâ€™s father also conveyed to Wife a one-ninth interest in Kensington Apartments, LLC (Kensington), which owned and managed one hundred sixty-eight apartment units.Â  Wife received an income from Kensington of $2,500 per month.Â  Â 
In March 2002, Wife discovered Husband was having an affair, and she and Brittany moved to one of the apartment units at Kensington.Â  On April 4, 2002, Wife filed the underlying action, seeking divorce on the ground of adultery, custody of Brittany, child support, alimony, and equitable division of the marital estate.Â  Husband admitted his misconduct and also requested equitable division of the marital estate.Â  At the temporary hearing, the family court awarded Wife custody of Brittany and ordered Husband to pay $1,800 a month in unallocated support.Â  
The final hearing was held in October 2003. Â Husband and Wife agreed that the assets should, for the most part, be split evenly between the two.Â  Although Wife blamed the breakup of the marriage on Husbandâ€™s adultery, Husband blamed Wifeâ€™s overspending and the partiesâ€™ disagreements on rearing the children.Â  After hearing testimony from both Husband and Wife, the family court granted Wife a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  The family court found custody was not an issue because both children were over the age of eighteen, but the court ordered child support of $583 per month to support Brittany throughout her senior year of high school.Â  The court also ordered Husband to pay Wife periodic alimony in the amount of $1,200 per month.Â  
The court ordered a split of the remaining marital assets with forty-nine percent going to Husband and fifty-one percent going to Wife.Â  This included CF Enterprises, which Husband maintained was nonmarital.Â  The court ordered Husband to sell the marital home and awarded him eighty-five percent of the houseâ€™s proceeds after the mortgage was fully paid.Â  The court used the appraisal commissioned by Husband in assessing the value of the home for $650,000. Â Wife received several bank accounts and an IRA worth $250,000.Â  Finally, the court ordered Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and various fees for experts used in assessing the value of the marital property.Â  
Husband filed a timely motion to reconsider and argued, inter alia, that the marital home sold for $615,000 after the final hearing rather than the appraised value of $650,000.Â  Husband asserted that because the court awarded him eighty-five percent of the proceeds of the house, his share of the marital assets was substantially reduced and he received closer to forty percent rather than the fifty percent envisioned by the parties.Â  Further, Husband contended he was further prejudiced because the IRA, which the court awarded Wife, substantially increased after the final hearing.Â  On reconsideration, the court adjusted the distribution to account for the inadvertent double counting of the value of a life insurance policy and likewise reduced Wifeâ€™s interest in Husbandâ€™s 401k to effectuate a fifty-one/forty-nine split.Â  The court denied Husbandâ€™s requests to consider the post-hearing increase in the value of the IRA and the actual sales price of the marital home in adjusting the marital distribution. Â This appeal followed. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact the family court, who saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Â Â Â Â  Equitable Division
We first consider the equitable distribution award.Â  Husband argues the family courtâ€™s error in using the value of the marital home and the IRA provided at the time of the final hearing resulted in Husband receiving only a forty-two percent distribution of the marital assets.Â  Specifically, Husband contends that in the six months between the time of the final hearing and when the family court issued the divorce decree, the marital home sold for $35,000 less than the appraisal and the IRA that was awarded to Wife increased in value by $40,000.Â  Therefore, Husband maintains the family courtâ€™s error resulted in his distribution of the marital estate being only forty-two percent rather than the fifty percent the parties agreed to.Â  We disagree.Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Time of Valuation 
Generally, in South Carolina marital property subject to equitable distribution is valued as of the date marital litigation is commenced.Â  Fields v. Fields, 342 S.C. 182, 186, 536 S.E.2d 684, 686 (Ct. App. 2000); see Jamar v. Jamar, 308 S.C. 265, 267, 417 S.E.2d 615, 616 (Ct. App. 1992) (â€œThe proper date to value marital property is the time the marital litigation is filed or commenced.â€). Â Â However, â€œthe parties may be entitled to share in any appreciation or depreciation in marital assets occurring after separation but before divorce.â€Â  Fields, 342 S.C. at 186, 536 S.E.2d at 686 (emphasis added); Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 228, 512 S.E.2d 539, 542 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œ[G]iven the volume of cases handled by our family courts, there often is a substantial delay between commencement of an action and its ultimate resolution.Â  Thus, it is not unusual for the value of marital assets to change, sometimes substantially, between the time the action was commenced and its final resolution.Â  In such a case, the family court has the ability to consider the post-filing appreciation or depreciation when valuing and apportioning the marital estate.â€).
In the present case, Husband argues the family court erred in the date on which it valued the marital home and the IRA.Â  Initially, we note that the family court valued the IRA at $250,798.Â  The family court used the IRAâ€™s value on the date the final hearing was held rather than the value on the date litigation was commenced.Â  Although the family court did not specify a reason for departing from the general rule that the valuation occurs the date litigation begins, we find the departure benefited Husband.Â  The family court awarded Wife the IRA and any increase in value was taken into account because the family court gave each party nearly fifty percent of the marital estate.Â  
Husband cites Mallet v. Mallet, 323 S.C. 141, 473 S.E.2d 804 (Ct. App. 1996), for the proposition that when marital property depreciates or appreciates through no fault of either party, it would be â€œgrossly unfairâ€ not to adjust the value.Â  Mallet, 323 S.C. at 151, 473 S.E.2d at 810.Â  Husband fails to realize, however, that Mallet affirmed valuation of a spouseâ€™s business at the time of the final hearing where the business had declined in value since commencement of the divorce action.Â  Id.Â  We are aware of no case law, and Husband points to none, that requires the family court to reassess any increase in value that occurs after the final hearing.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err by failing to consider the IRAâ€™s increase after the final hearing.Â  
A real estate appraiser, hired by Husband, testified at the final hearing that the value of the marital home was $650,000.[2]Â  The final hearing occurred in October 2003, the family court issued the divorce decree on April 2, 2004, and the house sold on May 12, 2004, for $615,000.Â  Because the house sold after the family court issued the divorce decree, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s failure to reconsider the valuation of the house.Â  Further, the family court has broad discretion in valuing marital property, and we discern no error in the courtâ€™s reliance on the value presented by Husbandâ€™s expert.Â  See Fields, 342 S.C. at 187, 536 S.E.2d at 686 (â€œThe family court has broad discretion in valuing marital property such that this Court will affirm when the findings below are supported by the evidence.â€).
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Distribution
Husband argues the distribution of the partiesâ€™ assets and debts were unfair to him because the family courtâ€™s valuation of the house and IRA resulted in Husband receiving only forty-two percent of the marital assets.Â  We disagree.
Absent an abuse of discretion, the apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 58, 606 S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  On appeal, we look to the overall fairness of the apportionment and if the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant if we would have arrived at a different apportionment.Â  Id.  
In determining an equitable distribution of marital property, the family court must identify, value, and then equitably apportion the property.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 288 S.C. 270, 276, 341 S.E.2d 811, 815 (Ct. App. 1986).Â Â  The court must consider several factors in making an equitable distribution.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2005) (outlining fifteen factors for the family court to consider in equitable distribution).Â  Included in those factors is the marital misconduct of either party.Â  S.C. Code Ann Â§ 20-7-472(2) (Supp. 2005) (noting that marital fault is one of the factors to be considered). 
At the final hearing, both parties indicated they believed a fifty-fifty split of the marital assets would be fair.Â  In equitably dividing the marital estate, the family court relied on the values of the assets presented at trial, including the $650,000 value of the marital home and the then-current value of the IRA. Â The award to Wife amounted to fifty-one percent of the marital estate, while the Husbandâ€™s award was forty-nine percent.Â  At the hearing on the motion for reconsideration, the family court realized that one asset was counted twice.Â  The court requested assistance from the partiesâ€™ attorneys on how best to recalculate the distribution to stay within the â€œ49/51 split.â€Â  The order on reconsideration adjusted the distribution to stay within those percentages.Â Â  Â 
As previously addressed, we believe the family court did not abuse its discretion in relying on the values of the home and the IRA at the time of the final hearing.Â  Although the marital home was still for sale at the time of the final hearing, thus the final value was uncertain, Husbandâ€™s appraisal valued the home at $650,000.Â  The court awarded Husband eighty-five percent of the houseâ€™s proceeds.Â  In light of the fact the court attributed the break-up of the marriage to Husbandâ€™s infidelity, it was not unfair that Husband should be the bearer of the risk that the house should sell for less than the appraisal.Â  Likewise, the increase or decrease in the value of the IRA after the final hearing was uncertain and subject to fluctuating market conditions.Â  We find no error with the courtâ€™s failure to predict the uncertainties of the market in making a final distribution.Â  
The family court effectuated a nearly even split of the marital assets given the definite values presented at the final hearing.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family court.[3]Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony
Husband argues the family court erred in ordering him to pay Wife permanent periodic alimony in the amount of $1,200 per month.Â  Husband contends the family court failed to take into account Wifeâ€™s considerable nonmarital assets.Â  We agree.
Alimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital relationship, and its purpose is to place the supported spouse as close to the position of support enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The decision to grant or deny alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Williams v. Williams, 297 S.C. 208, 210, 375 S.E.2d 349, 350 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œAlimony should not dissuade a spouse, to the extent possible, from becoming self-supporting.â€ Â Rimer v. Rimer, 361 S.C. 521, 525, 605 S.E.2d 572, 574 (Ct. App. 2004). Â There are several factors the family court must consider in deciding whether to award alimony: 

(1) the duration of the marriage and the ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and at separation; (2) the physical and emotional condition of each spouse; (3) the educational background of each spouse and the need for additional education; (4) the employment history and earning potential of each spouse; (5) the standard of living established during the marriage; (6) the current and reasonably anticipated income of each spouse; (7) the current and reasonably anticipated expenses of each spouse; (8) the marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) the custody of any children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) the tax consequences of the award; (12) the existence of support obligations to a former spouse; and (13) such other factors the court considers relevant.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005); Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886 (1994) (noting the statute â€œsets forth 12 factors which must be weighed when determining alimonyâ€).Â  The family court may weigh these factors as it finds appropriate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005) (â€œIn making an award of alimony . . . the court must consider and give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors.â€).
At the temporary hearing, Wife submitted a financial declaration showing expenses for herself and Brittany, then eighteen, of $4,358 per month.Â  Without explanation, Wifeâ€™s financial declaration at the final hearing showed expenses of $9,243 per month.Â  After Husband and Wife separated, Wife purchased a home for herself from Kensington for $200,000[4] and extensively remodeled the home for an additional $100,000.Â  Wife also managed to save $50,000, and her nonmarital assets were valued at $603,901.Â  Â 
In the final order, the family court found Wife had primarily been a homemaker and mother.Â  The court found that Wife had an income of $2,500 per month from Kensington and then imputed to her an additional earning capacity of $1,200.Â  In assessing Wifeâ€™s income, the court did not include any future payments from Maxwell Family because the amount Wife would receive in the future was too uncertain.Â  The court reasoned that Wife would no longer have income from Fulco, which was awarded to Husband, and that her employment decisions changed as a result of her role as homemaker and mother.Â  The court found that even though Husbandâ€™s financial declaration showed a monthly deficit, with expenses of $7,795.18 and a net income of only $4,986, he had been able to pay the $1,800 a month of unallocated support to Wife that was granted at the temporary hearing, stating â€œ[a]lthough [Husband] shows a monthly deficit it is obvious . . . he has the ability to make the alimony payment out of his income as he has done so . . . and . . . the most recent financial declaration does not reflect [Husband] has incurred an additional indebtedness nor invaded any assets to meet his monthly deficit.â€Â  In the portion of the order addressing Wifeâ€™s entitlement to alimony, the court merely stated that Wife had â€œdemonstrated a need and [Husband] has shown an ability to pay alimony.â€Â Â  
It is difficult for this court to discern what factors the family court considered in awarding Wife alimony.Â  The family court only cited Husbandâ€™s ability to pay and Wifeâ€™s â€œneedâ€ in awarding alimony.Â  It is unclear which of Wifeâ€™s financial declarations the court relied upon in determining Wifeâ€™s â€œneed.â€Â  It does not appear the court considered that Wifeâ€™s expenses nearly doubled from the time between the temporary and final hearing.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(7) (Supp. 2005) (stating that court must consider â€œthe current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of both spousesâ€).[5]Â  It is also unclear whether the court considered Wifeâ€™s substantial nonmarital assets in determining her â€œneed.â€Â  Moreover, the family courtâ€™s order did not state how it arrived at Wifeâ€™s imputed income nor did it consider the fact that Husbandâ€™s testimony revealed that he incurred approximately $49,000 to $50,000 worth of debt since the couple separated.Â  
We recognize that the family court could weigh the statutory factors as it deemed appropriate.Â  Because the court relied only on Wifeâ€™s need and Husbandâ€™s ability to pay alimony in making its determination, we believe the court erred by not also considering Wifeâ€™s nonmarital assets.Â  Further, although different portions of the order note the length of the marriage, the partiesâ€™ health, Husbandâ€™s infidelity, and Wifeâ€™s income potential, it does not appear from the order that the court considered these matters in awarding alimony.Â  We agree with Husband that the family court failed to consider all the statutory factors in awarding Wife alimony.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the alimony award and remand the matter for a hearing to determine Wifeâ€™s entitlement to alimony based upon a consideration of all the statutory factors.
III.Â Â Â  CF Enterprises
Husband contends the family court erred in finding CF Enterprises was a marital asset.Â  He argues the money used to start the company was a gift from his aunt and is a nonmarital asset.Â  We disagree.
Marital property is generally defined as all real and personal property acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation, regardless of how legal title is held.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2005).Â  However, property is considered nonmarital if it is acquired by gift or inheritance. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1) (Supp. 2005).Â  Because of the general presumption that property acquired during the marriage is an asset of the marriage, the burden to show an asset is nonmarital is upon the party claiming the nonmarital status.Â  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 356, 396 S.E.2d 124, 126 (Ct. App. 1990).
CF Enterprises had two stockholders, Husband and his cousin, and they started it with an initial investment of $15,000 each.Â  Husband maintains no marital money was used to start or finance the company and that the money he used was a gift from his aunt.Â  Wife contends the money Husband used was a loan from his aunt.Â  During the hearing, Husband offered no proof by way of check or testimony that CF Enterprises was nonmarital.Â  Additionally, his financial declaration stated the source of the company was a â€œloan.â€Â  Because Husband did not produce evidence to rebut the presumption that CF Enterprises was marital, we find the family court did not err.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that CF Enterprises was an asset of the marriage.
IV.Â Â Â  Expert Fees
Finally, the Husband contests the award of expert fees to Wife.Â  He maintains Wife failed to produce evidence to support the award.Â  We agree.
Although alimony and suit money is provided for by statute, â€œthe claim must be â€˜well foundedâ€™ [and the] burden of proving that a claim is well founded is on the party seeking suit money.â€ Â Taylor v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 209, 220, 508 S.E.2d 50, 56 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-120); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-120 (Supp. 2005) (noting that a party in a divorce action may request attorneyâ€™s fees and costs and the court shall grant a reasonable sum if the claim appears â€œwell-foundedâ€).
The family court ordered Husband to pay $2,222 for Wifeâ€™s forensic economist and $682 for copies of documents Wife made for the C.P.A.Â  Wife testified that forensic economist Dr. Charles Alford gave her â€œa wonderful three or four page sheet with the little details that [she] needed to think of what [she] would spend.â€Â  Dr. Alford did not testify nor did Wife affirmatively establish what services he performed.Â  Further, Wife testified that she paid for $682 worth of copies from the C.P.A. but produced no receipt.Â  Wife had the burden to establish her claim was well-founded.Â  Because she produced no evidence supporting the award of fees other than her brief reference to their existence, we find the family court abused its discretion in ordering Husband to pay these fees.Â  Accordingly, we reverse these awards.

CONCLUSION

For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
 HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Maxwell Family has a one-third interest in Maxwell Road Developers.
[2] Despite the appraisal, Husband listed the house for $669,000 and the house remained on the market for over a year before selling.Â  
[3] Â Husband also argues that the family court erred in awarding him the Thornblade Country Club membership because neither party would benefit from it once the house in the Thornblade community was sold.Â  However, in his motion for reconsideration and in his arguments at the motion hearing, Husband argued the family court erred in the value assigned to the membership because he would be unable to sell it.Â  Because Husband did not raise the lack of â€œbenefitâ€ argument before the family court below, it is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding that an issue not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge is not preserved for appellate review).Â  Similarly, Husbandâ€™s argument that the family court unfairly considered his adultery in equitably dividing the property was not raised before the family court and is not preserved.Â  Id.Â  
[4] Kensington bought the house for $269,000 and then Wife bought the house from Kensington for $200,000 with a bank loan.Â  
[5] There was also some evidence Wifeâ€™s financial declaration was inflated.Â  For example, Wifeâ€™s financial declaration shows an expense of $457 per month for Brittanyâ€™s private high school when her testimony revealed a family trust pays for Brittanyâ€™s schooling.Â

title: State v. Geiger
description: Eddie Geiger appeals his conviction for assault with intent to commit first degree sexual conduct (ACSC).  Geiger argues the trial court erred in refusing his request to charge the jury with assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) as a lesser included offense.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State Respondent,
v.
Eddie Geiger Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4151
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, all Â of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Eddie Geiger (Geiger) was convicted of assault with intent to commit first degree sexual conduct (ACSC) and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.Â  Geiger appeals, arguing the trial court erred in refusing his request to charge the jury with assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) as a lesser included offense.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the early morning hours of January 31, 2003, Annie J. placed a 911 call reporting she had been sexually assaulted in her home. Â The responding law enforcement officials and emergency medical technicians arrived at the abode to find the nearly seventy-year-old woman recently battered and cut, very frightened and with blood on her face.Â  Geigerâ€™s driverâ€™s license was found on the coffee table and his clothing was discovered in the bathroom. Â Before being sent to the hospital, Annie J. identified Geiger as her assailant.Â  
Geiger was arrested and indicted for ACSC.Â  At trial, Annie J. detailed the eveningâ€™s events, albeit at times she was somewhat difficult to decipher, her speech slurred from an earlier stroke. Â She testified that Geiger was an acquaintance of her sonâ€™s and had been in her house on several previous occasions.Â  Although Geigerâ€™s appearance at her home was uninvited on this particular evening, she had voluntarily allowed him inside.Â  Annie J. averred that, at his request, she provided Geiger with a liquor drink.Â  She did not imbibe.Â  In recounting her attack, Annie J. said after excusing himself to the bathroom, Geiger returned naked and brandishing her pistol.Â  Although at times in her testimony, Annie J. seemed uncertain as to the exact location and chronology of the events, she unequivocally described Geigerâ€™s behavior and acts against her.Â  She stated that Geiger demanded she give him money, slapped her in the head repeatedly, put the gun to her head, put his penis in her mouth, and attempted to force her legs apart to have sexual intercourse with her.Â  She asseverated she was able to prevent him from penetrating her and that, after the physical attack ended, Geiger searched her home for money and then left.
The emergency personnel responding to Annie J.â€™s telephone call described the victim as being very frightened and upset and recounted that her home was in a state of disarray. Â The sexual assault nurse who treated her at the hospital opined that Annie J.â€™s injuries were consistent with her description of the events.Â  DNA tests conclusively indicated the clothes found in the bathroom had been worn by Geiger. 
Geiger did not testify in his own defense.Â  He called no witnesses, but limited his defense to cross-examination of the prosecutionâ€™s witnesses. 
At the close of the evidence, Geigerâ€™s attorney requested a charge of ABHAN. Â The circuit court refused the inclusion of the lesser charge, stating the record was devoid of evidence that Geiger committed ABHAN rather than ACSC. Â The jury found Geiger guilty of ACSC.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. Â State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion. Â State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 623 S.E.2d 122 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004). Â In order for an error of law to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant. Â State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); see State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995).
This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); Patterson, 367 S.C. at 224, 625 S.E.2d at 241; State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We do not reassess the facts based on our own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determine whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003). Â This Court should examine the record to determine whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling. Â See Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Davis, 364 S.C. 364, 613 S.E.2d 760 (Ct. App. 2005); Mattison, 352 S.C. at 583, 575 S.E.2d at 855.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. ABHAN as a Lesser Included Offense of ACSC
On appeal, Geiger argues the trial court erred in failing to charge ABHAN as lesser included offense of ACSC.Â  Specifically, Geiger contends the evidence presented at trial supported an inference that he was guilty solely of the lesser included crime.Â  We disagree.
Geiger was convicted of assault with intent to commit criminal sexual conduct.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-652 (2003) provides:

(1) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim and if any one or more of the following circumstances are proven:
  
(a) The actor uses aggravated force to accomplish sexual battery.Â  
(b) The victim submits to sexual battery by the actor under circumstances where the victim is also the victim of forcible confinement, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, burglary, housebreaking, or any other similar offense or act.
  

Sexual battery is defined as â€œsexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio, anal intercourse, or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of a personâ€™s body or of any object into the genital or anal openings of another personâ€™s body, except when such intrusion is accomplished for medically recognized treatment or diagnostic purposes.â€ Â S.C. Â Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h) (2003).
ABHAN is â€œan unlawful act of violent injury accompanied by circumstances of aggravation.â€ Â State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 580, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002). Â As an element of ABHAN, circumstances of aggravation include, inter alia, the use of a deadly weapon, intent to commit a felony, infliction of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or physical conditions of the parties, difference in gender, taking indecent liberties or familiarities with a female, purposeful infliction of shame and disgrace, and resistance to lawful authority. Â State v. Frazier, 302 S.C. 500, 397 S.E.2d 93 (1990); State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 21, 518 S.E.2d 278, 285 (Ct. App. 1999); State v. Murphy, 322 S.C. 321, 471 S.E.2d 739 (Ct. App. 1996).
ABHAN is a lesser included offense of ACSC, notwithstanding that technically ACSC does not contain all of the elements of ABHAN.Â  State v. Elliot, 346 S.C. 603, 606, 552 S.E.2d 727, 728 (2001), overruled in part on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005); State v. Drafts, 288 S.C. 30, 340 S.E.2d 784 (1986).Â  Under the elements test, a crime will only be considered a lesser offense if the greater crime encompasses all of the elements of the lesser.Â  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d. 773, 777 (1998).Â  However, we have recognized limited exceptions where an offense has traditionally been considered a lesser included offense of the greater.Â  Noting that ABHAN was historically considered a lesser included offense to ACSCâ€™s predecessor, assault with intent to ravage, the supreme court has expressly held ABHAN to be a lesser included offense of ACSC.Â  Elliot, 346 S.C at 606, 552 S.E.2d at 728; Drafts, 288 S.C. at 30, 340 S.E.2d at 784.
II. Charging Lesser Included Offenses
While upon indictment for a greater offense a trial court has the requisite jurisdiction to charge and convict a defendant of any lesser included offense,Â  see Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 465 S.E.2d 358 (1995), overruled in part on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 233, 522 S.E.2d 845, 854 (Ct. App. 1999); Tyndall, 336 S.C. at 21, 518 S.E.2d at 285, a lesser included offense instruction is required only when the evidence warrants such an instruction.Â  State v. Mitchell, 362 S.C. 289, 301, 608 S.E.2d 140, 143 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Coleman, 342 S.C. 172, 175 536 S.E.2d 387, 389 (Ct. App. 2000). Â â€œThe law to be charged is determined by the evidence presented at trial.â€ State v. Gourdine, 322 S.C. 396, 398, 472 S.E.2d 241 (1996) (emphasis added); accord, State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Todd; 290 S.C. 212, 214, 349 S.E.2d 339, 341 (1986).Â  To justify charging the lesser crime, the evidence presented must allow a rational inference the defendant was guilty only of the lesser offense.Â  See Tyndall, 336 S.C. at 22, 518 S.E.2d at 285.Â  The court looks to the totality of evidence in evaluating whether such an inference has been created.Â  See id. (in deciding whether the evidence tended to show the defendant was guilty of the lesser included offense, the court looked at the â€œreasonable inference[s] to be drawn from the totality of the evidenceâ€).Â  The trial court should refuse to charge the lesser included offense when there has been no evidence tending to show the defendant may have committed solely the lesser offense.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 446 S.E.2d 411 (1994).
Geiger recites the well established rule that, â€œ[t]he trial judge is to charge a jury on a lesser included offense if there is any evidence from which it could be inferred that the lesser, rather than the greater, offense was committed.â€Â  State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 375, 563 S.E.2d 336, 337 (2002); Gourdine, 322 S.C. at 398, 472 S.E.2d at 241; accord Brighton v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 350-351, 520 S.E.2d 614 615 (1999); State v. Mathis, 287 S.C. 589, 594, 340 S.E.2d 538, 541 (1986).Â  Conversely, â€œ[a] lesser included offense instruction is required only when the evidence warrants such an instruction, and it is not error to refuse to charge the lesser included offense unless there is evidence tending to show the defendant was guilty only of the lesser offense.â€Â  Tyndall, 336 S.C. at Â 21, 518 S.E. 2d 278, 285; accord State v. White, 361 S.C. 407, 412, 605 S.E.2d 540, 543 (2004); State v. Cooney (320 S.C. 107, 112, 463 S.E.2d 597, 600 (1995); Murphy, 322 S.C. at 326, 471 S.E.2d at 741.
In State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. at 233, 522 S.E.2d at 854, the court edified: â€œ[i]n order to justify a charge of a lesser included offense, the evidence must be capable of sustaining either the greater or the lesser offense, depending on the juryâ€™s view of the facts.â€Â  See Tyndall, 336 S.C. at 21-22, 518 S.E.2d at 285; State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92, 94, 413 S.E.2d 870, 871 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The rule is articulated with exactitude in Dempsey v. State: â€œA judge is required to charge a jury on a lesser-included offense â€˜if there is any evidence from which it could be inferred the lesser, rather than the greater, offense was committed.â€™â€ 363 S.C. 365, 371, 610 S.E.2d 812, 815 (2005) (emphasis omitted from the original) (quoting Gourdine, 322 S.C. at 398, 472 S.E.2d at 242).
III. Application in the Case Sub Judice
Geiger contends the evidence presented at trial was sufficient to support an ABHAN instruction.Â  In furtherance of this position, he professes that the victimâ€™s testimony was â€œcurious,â€ opining it would be unlikely for Annie J. to have invited him into her home for late night â€œBiblical talkâ€ and a drink of vodka.Â  Implicitly, he asserts: (1) her age and medical history may have impaired her ability to recount the events of the evening in question and (2) Annie J.â€™s testimony exposed some confusion as to the chronological order and exact room where certain events during the attack occurred.Â  Geiger admits the state presented considerable evidence showing that he was in Annie J.â€™s home at the time she was assailed; however, he advances the position that no forensic evidence of sexual assault was ever produced.
The mere contention that the jury might accept the Stateâ€™s evidence in part and reject it in part is insufficient to satisfy the requirement that some evidence tend to show the defendant was guilty only of the lesser offense.Â  See State v. Funchess, 267 S.C. 427, 229 S.E.2d 331 (1976) (â€œthe [p]resence of evidence to sustain the crime of a lesser degree determines whether it should be submitted to the jury and the â€˜mere contention that the jury might accept the Stateâ€™s evidence in part and might reject it in part will not suffice.â€™â€) (quoting State v. Hicks, 241 N.C. 156, 159-160, 84 S.E.2d 545, 547 (1954));Â  see also Tyndall, at 22, 518 S.E.2d at 285 (possibility that the jury might have disbelieved the Stateâ€™s evidence as to the circumstances of aggravation and on the remaining evidence found the defendant guilty of simple assault and battery did not entitle the defendant to have the lesser offense submitted to the jury where there was no evidence tending to show defendant was guilty only of simple assault and battery); State v. Rucker, 319 S.C. 95, 98-99, 459 S.E.2d 858, 860 (Ct. App. 1995) (contention that the jury might have disbelieved the Stateâ€™s evidence as to the circumstances of aggravation and on the remaining evidence found appellant guilty of the lesser offense of simple assault and battery did not entitle her to have the lesser offense submitted to the jury where appellant presented no evidence she committed some act that could be viewed by the jury as a simple assault); State v. Hartley, 307 S.C. 239, 241-42, 414 S.E.2d 182, 184 (Ct. App. 1992) (where there was no evidence that showed defendant killed victim without malice, trial judge did not err in refusing to charge the jury on the crime of manslaughter as a lesser-included offense of the crime of murder); State v. Foxworth, 269 S.C. 496, 499, 238 S.E.2d 172, 173 (1977) (possibility that the jury might have disbelieved the Stateâ€™s evidence as to the circumstances of aggravation in ABHAN trial and on the remaining evidence found defendant guilty of the lesser offense of simple assault and battery did not entitle him to have the lesser offense submitted to the jury where all the evidence admitted at trial pointed to the appellantâ€™s guilt of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature).
The supreme courtâ€™s analysis in Dempsey v. State is particularly instructive.Â  363 S.C. 365, 610 S.E.2d 812 (2005).Â  In appealing his conviction for sexually assaulting his stepson, Dempsey asserted, inter alia, that the evidence warranted having ABHAN charged to the jury.Â  At trial, the victim testified that on multiple occasions Dempsey forced him to perform various sexual acts.Â  Additionally, the victim and his aunt both gave testimony as to occasions when Dempsey acted violently toward the victim.Â  In holding an ABHAN charge was not required, the supreme court found there was no evidence from which it could be inferred that ABHAN rather than ACSC was committed.Â  The court reasoned that while there was evidence of conduct that could be construed as ABHAN, none of the incidents was alleged to have occurred instead of the sexual batteries. Â Id.
In State v. Fields our court addressed a similar factual and legal scenario with academic precision.Â  356 S.C. 517, 589 S.E.2d 792 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The victim testified that Fields used a combination of trickery, threats, and physical force to get her into an abandoned house, where, once inside, he threw her about the structure, ordered her to perform sexual acts, and forced her to have intercourse.Â  In addition to the victimâ€™s testimony, the prosecution presented expert testimony that her injuries were consistent with someone who had been sexually assaulted and that semen found in her underwear matched that of the defendant.Â  Fields, who did not testify or present any evidence on his own behalf, was convicted of criminal sexual conduct.Â  On appeal he argued the jury could reasonably have found the sex consensual by disbelieving a portion of the victimâ€™s testimony and that he was therefore entitled to jury instructions on ABHAN.Â  The court concluded the mere contention the jury might have disbelieved the Stateâ€™s evidence that the sex was forced and on the remaining evidence found him guilty of ABHAN did not entitle Fields to have the lesser charge submitted to the jury.Â  Although recognizing that at trial the defense counsel suggested the sex was willful, the court nonetheless found the record devoid of any evidence tending to show Fields guilty only of ABHAN, noting that both the victimâ€™s testimony of her assault and the attending physicianâ€™s opinion that her injuries indicated nonconsensual sex were uncontested.Â  Id. Â 
Geiger relies upon two cases, State v. Gourdine, 322 S.C. 396, 472 S.E.2d 241 (1996), and State v. Mathis, 287 S.C. 589, 340 S.E.2d 538 (1986), which can be clearly distinguished from the case at hand. Â In Mathis, the defendant was charged with the crime of criminal sexual conduct (CSC) in the first degree for engaging in sexual battery with a victim less than eleven years old (assault with intent to commit CSC was not charged).Â  At trial, the victim testified the defendant touched her with his penis, but also stated she could not remember if he ever put it inside her.Â  The greater crime, CSC, required some â€œintrusion, however slightâ€ of the victim. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h) (2003). Â Thus, the victimâ€™s uncertainly on this issue served as evidence on which a jury could find the defendant committed the lesser, rather the greater, offense.Â  In Gourdine, the greater crime at issue, armed robbery, required use of a deadly weapon.Â  At trial, three different witnesses testified that a BB gun, water gun, toy, or fake gun was used in the commission of the robbery, which the court held was sufficient evidence from which the jury could have found the lesser crime of strong arm robbery had been committed.
The trial record in the case at bar contains no evidence tending to show Geiger may have assaulted Annie J. but not attempted a sexual battery.Â  The victimâ€™s undisputed testimony recounting Geigerâ€™s efforts to sexually assault her supports only an ACSC instruction, not one of ABHAN.Â  Barring some confusion as to the precise location where the events transpired, Annie J. consistently reported exactly what occurred.Â  She verified, without contradiction, that Geiger came out of the bathroom naked, put a gun to her head, hit her repeatedly on the head, forced his penis into her mouth, and tried to force her legs open to have intercourse with her.Â  Her testimony was further corroborated by the discovery of Geigerâ€™s clothes in her bathroom, her physical injuries, and the testimony of witnesses as to her mental state and demeanor immediately following the incident.Â  It is inconsequential that there was no forensic evidence of sexual assault.Â  The medical examiner testified that Annie J.â€™s injuries were consistent with the victimâ€™s narrative of the events and that the lack of direct evidence of a sexual assault conformed with Annie J.â€™s testimony that Geiger was never able to penetrate her.
The trial judge did not err in denying Geigerâ€™s request to charge the lesser included offense of ABHAN. Â There is no evidence tending to show Geiger was guilty solely of the lesser crime. Â The only reasonable inference to be drawn from the totality of the evidence was that Geiger either did or did not commit ACSC.Â  The mere contestation that the jury might have disbelieved Annie J.â€™s testimony as to the sexual acts and nature of Geigerâ€™s assault does not entitle him to have the jury charged with the lesser offense of ABHAN.
CONCLUSION 
Because the record is devoid of evidence that Geiger was guilty only of the lesser included offense, the trial court did not err by refusing to charge the jury with ABHAN.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.
