description: Warren C. Powell, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent CBS Surveying and Mapping, Inc.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Bennett, Richard K. Bennett, James M.
Hendershot, and Robert N. Parker, III, Appellants, 
v.
Investors Title Insurance Company, Respondent, 
      
    
  



  
    
      
         Investors Title Insurance Company,
        Respondent,
        
          
            
              
v.
              
            
          
        
Crescent Resources, LLC, Bristol, LLC and CBS Surveying & Mapping,
Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
__________
Opinion No. 4152
Heard September 12, 2006 â€“ Filed September 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Randall S. Hiller, of Greenville, for Appellants.
Louis H. Lang, of Columbia, for Respondent Investors Title Insurance Company.
V. Clark Price, of Greenville and Benjamin A. Johnson, both of Rock Hill, for Respondent Crescent Resources, LLC.
Warren C. Powell, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent CBS Surveying and Mapping, Inc. 
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this dispute over liability for a surveying error, Kenneth E. Bennett, Richard K. Bennett, James M. Hendershot, and Robert N. Parker, III, (collectively Appellants), appeal the circuit courtâ€™s orders granting summary judgment to Crescent Resources, LLC and Investors Title Insurance Company.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 28, 2001, Crescent conveyed 47.82 acres of real property in Oconee County (the Property) to Bristol, LLC for $2.5 million.Â Â  Crescentâ€™s deed to Bristol (the Deed), entitled â€œSpecial Warranty Deed,â€ contains a granting clause referring to an attached property description, which, in turn, incorporates a plat (the Plat).Â  CBS Surveying and Mapping, Inc. prepared the Plat for Crescent on December 22, 2000.Â  The Plat shows a sixty-six foot right-of-way easement, entitled â€œSC 188 KEOWEE SCHOOL RD (66â€™ R/W),â€ on the western boundary of the Property.Â Â  
The habendum clause of the Deed reads, in pertinent part:

TO HAVE AND TO HOLD all and singular the Property, unto the said Grantee and Granteeâ€™s heirs, successors and assigns forever, except:
  
Â . . . .
Â (5) matters affecting title to the Property as shown on the Plat or which would be shown on a current and accurate survey of the Property (including any encroachments);
(6) easements, covenants, restrictions and conditions of record, and rights-of-way of public and private streets and roads, including, but not limited to, the road shown on the Plat as â€œold road bedâ€ and the sixty-six (66) foot wide road right-of-way shown on the Plat as â€œSC 188 Keowee School Road (66â€™ R/W)â€ . . . .
  

The Deed further provides that Crescent â€œcovenants to warrant specially the title to the Property against the lawful claims of any person claiming from, through, or under it.â€Â  
Later on the same day, Bristol conveyed the Property by general warranty deed to Appellants.Â  Anticipating this conveyance, Investors issued a title insurance commitment to Executive Properties, LLC.Â  This commitment agreed to provide an ownerâ€™s title insurance policy to Executive.[1]Â  On January 4, 2002, Appellants procured from Investors an ownerâ€™s title insurance policy (the Policy) covering the Property.Â  The Policy expressly â€œdoes not insure against loss or damage (and [Investors] will not pay costs, attorneysâ€™ fees or expenses) which arise by reason of . . . [s]uch state of facts as would be disclosed by a current and accurate survey of said premises.â€Â  Â 
Subsequently, Appellants built two brick walls within forty-one feet of the centerline of South Carolina Highway 188.Â  On April 25, 2002, the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) wrote Appellants, informing them SCDOT had a 200 foot right-of-way easement over the Property.Â  This right-of-way easement, dated August 1, 1968, and recorded at SCDOT shows Crescent granted the 200 foot right-of-way to SCDOT.[2]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-550 (2006) (directing all rights-of-way for state highways be filed at SCDOT). Â 
Presumably, Appellants notified Investors of this problem and demanded payment for their loss.Â  Investors alleged Appellants offered to settle the claim for $85,225.Â  Investors explained Appellants arrived at this number by appraising the Property, dividing that number by the total number of acres included in the Property, and applying that per acre value to the acreage mistakenly assumed to be unencumbered.Â  Investors further claimed it rejected this demand because the eastern portion of the Property bordered a lake, and this acreage would be valued higher than the portion bordering Highway 188.Â  Investors additionally asserted it hired the same appraiser Appellants used to value the specific acreage lost.Â  This appraiser valued the lost acreage at $64,000. 
As a result, Investors sent Appellants a settlement check in the amount of $64,000 and a settlement agreement, which Appellants never executed.Â  Investors explained Appellants hired a different attorney, who rejected the settlement offer and demanded $196,800 to settle the claim, including the â€œvalue of the improvements that were required to be relocated and/or destroyed due to the title defect . . . .â€Â  Investors refused to pay this amount, claiming the title policy excluded consequential damages.Â  Appellants eventually agreed to settle the claim for the lost value of the Property for $64,000 but retained its consequential damages claim. 
On June 26, 2003, Appellants filed a complaint against Investors, alleging breach of the title insurance contract and bad faith.Â  Investors answered and eventually filed an amended answer, including a third-party complaint against Crescent, Bristol, and CBS.Â  Appellants then filed an amended complaint, alleging a breach of deed warranty by Crescent and Bristol and negligence by CBS.Â  Crescent filed separate answers to Appellantsâ€™ amended complaint and Investorsâ€™ third-party complaint.[3]Â  
In June 2004, Investors moved for summary judgment against Appellants, explaining it attempted to settle the claim and Appellants had not answered its settlement offer.Â  According to Investors, the circuit court held a hearing on this motion, at which the parties discovered they possessed two different title insurance policy jackets with identical policy inserts.Â  The jacket relied upon by Investors excepted claims for consequential damages.Â  The circuit court allowed the parties time to supplement their arguments and Investors time to amend its motion.Â  
In August, Investors filed an amended motion for summary judgment against Appellants.Â  On January 11, 2005, Crescent moved for summary judgment against both Appellants and Investors.Â  In February 2005, Investors again amended its motion for summary judgment. 
The circuit court granted Crescentâ€™s motion for summary judgment against both Appellants and Investors, holding exceptions (5) and (6) in the Deedâ€™s habendum clause limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.Â  Furthermore, the circuit court applied this ruling to Investors, finding Investors could not recover more than Appellants could recover.Â  Although not included in the record, Appellants and Investors filed motions to reconsider this order, which the circuit court denied.Â Â  However, the court entered an amended order, correcting minor factual errors.Â  
Summary judgment was granted to Investors with respect to Appellantsâ€™ breach of contract and bad faith claims.Â  The circuit court held the Policy specifically excluded all matters a current and accurate survey would disclose, including the claim asserted here.Â  Appellants appealed both summary judgment orders.[4]
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006); Miller v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 219, 616 S.E.2d 722, 729 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006); Eagle Container Co., LLCÂ  v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 620, 622 S.E.2d 733, 737 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go the jury. Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.E.2d 588, 595, 608 S.E.2d 587, 591 (Ct. App. 2005). Summary judgment is appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Law, 323 S.C. at 434, 629 S.E.2d at 648; BPS, Inc. v. Worthy, 362 S.C. 319, 325, 608 S.E.2d 155, 159 (Ct.App.2005). On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below. Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 25, 630 S.E.2d 474, 477 (2006); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 317, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct.App.2003) (stating that all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law. Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Miller, 365 S.C. at 220, 616 S.E.2d at 729; Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 608 S.E.2d 440 (Ct. App. 2004). Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied. Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Comm'n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct.App.2004). However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted. Rife v. Hitachi Const. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 214, 609 S.E.2d 565, 568 (Ct. App. 2005); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004). 
The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact. Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 228, 612 S.E.2d 719, 722 (Ct. App. 2005). The moving party may discharge the burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact by pointing out the absence of evidence to support the nonmoving partyâ€™s case. Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.E. 256, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002). Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings. Wogan v. Kunze, 366, S.C. 583, 591, 623, S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App. 2005). The nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial. Rife, 363 S.C. at 214, 609 S.E.2d at 568.
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder. Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); Eagle Container, 366 S.C. at 621, 622 S.E.2d at 738; Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 393, 593 S.E.2d 183, 186 (Ct.App.2004). Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues. Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 644, 594 S.E.2d 455, 462 (2004); Wogan, 366, S.C. at 592, 623, S.E.2d at 112; B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Appellants v. Crescent
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in holding exceptions (5) and (6) in the habendum clause of the Deed limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.Â  Â Appellants argue (1) the granting clause and its incorporation of the Plat created a representation or covenant of the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way;Â  (2) Crescent failed to convey 47.82 acres of real property, as provided in the property description of the Deed; (3) the habendum clause was ambiguous; and (4) the Deedâ€™s special warranty clause automatically protects Bristol and subsequent purchasers against claims created by Crescent; otherwise, the Deed would be a quitclaim deed.Â  We disagree.
A. Construction of the Deed
The construction of a clear and unambiguous deed is a question of
law for the court.Â  Hammond v. Lindsay, 277 S.C. 182, 184, 284 S.E.2d 581, 582 (1981); Hunt v. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 568, 595 S.E.2d 846, 848 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Vause v. Mikell, 290 S.C. 65, 68, 348 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œThe construction of an unambiguous deed is a question of law, not fact.â€).Â  â€œ â€˜[I]t is the duty of the court to construe deeds and determine their legal effect, where there is no such ambiguity as requires parol proof and submission to the jury.â€™ â€ Hunt, 358 S.C. at 569, 595 S.E.2d at 848 (quoting 26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 168 (2001)).
â€œOne of the first canons of construction of a deed is that the intention of the grantor must be ascertained and effectuated if no settled rule of law is contravened.â€Â  S. Ry. Co. v. Smoak, 243 S.C. 331, 336, 133 S.E.2d 806, 808 (1963); Wayburn v. Smith, 270 S.C. 38, 41, 239 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1977); Estate of Sherman ex rel. Maddock v. Estate of Sherman ex rel. Snodgrass, 359 S.C. 407, 413, 597 S.E.2d 850, 853 (Ct. App. 2004); see also McDaniel v. Connor, 206 S.C. 96, 100, 33 S.E.2d 75, 76 (1945) (â€œAs has many times been said, the governing principle in the construction of deeds is that the intention of the grantor, if consistent with law, shall govern.â€).Â  Moreover, in ascertaining such
intention, the deed must be construed as a whole and effect given to every part thereof, if such can be done consistently with law.Â  Wayburn, 270 S.C. at 42, 239 S.E.2d at 892; Bean v. Bean, 253 S.C. 340, 343, 170 S.E.2d 654, 655 (1969); Alexander v. Burnet, 39 S.C.L. (5 Rich.) 189, 196 (1851); see also First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia v. Ford, 177 S.C. 40, 46, 180 S.E. 562, 565 (1935) (â€œLarger and more sensible rules of construction require that the whole deed should be considered together, and effect be given to every part, if all can stand together consistently with law . . . . â€).
B. Clauses in the Deed
Guided by our mandate to read the Deed as a whole, we examine the specific clauses therein.Â  The term â€œpremisesâ€ is used to refer to â€œall that part of [a] deed preceding the habendum clause, containing generally the names or description of the parties; explanatory recitals, including consideration and its receipt; a description of the realty; the exception, if any; and sometimes a designation of the estate or interest conveyed.â€Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 35 (2001); see also Artis v. Artis, 47 S.E.2d 228, 232 (N.C. 1948) (â€œOrdinarily the premises and granting clauses designate the grantee and the thing granted, while the habendum clause relates to the quantum of the estate.â€).Â  
In South Carolina, the term â€œgranting clauseâ€ is used.Â  This court in Hunt v. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 566-67, 595 S.E.2d 846, 847 (Ct. App. 2004), referred to the following language in a deed as the â€œgranting clause:â€


The First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia . . . [has] granted, bargained, sold and released, and by these presents [does] grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said
[SCFC] and their successors in office all that certain piece . . . .

(emphasis removed); see also Estate of Sherman, 359 S.C. at 409, 597 S.E.2d at 850-51 (referring to similar language in another deed as the â€œgranting clauseâ€).Â  The granting clause in the Deed incorporates an attached property description which, in turn, incorporates the Plat.Â Â Â  
The Latin phrase â€œhabendum et tenendumâ€ means â€œto have and to hold.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 716 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Thus, in Hunt, 358 S.C. at 567, 595 S.E.2d at 847, this court quoted the habendum clause in that deed:Â  â€œTo Have and to Hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto the said [SCFC] and their successors in office, and assigns forever.â€Â  (emphasis removed); see also Smoak v. McClure, 236 S.C. 548, 549, 115 S.E.2d 55, 55 (1960) (â€œThe
habendum clause is regular in form, as follows:
â€˜To have and to hold, all and singular, the said premises before mentioned unto the said Ben Garris, and his Heirs and Assigns forever.â€™ â€).Â  
The habendum â€œis the clause usually following the granting part of the premises of a deed, which defines the extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the grantee.â€ 26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 36 (2001).Â  Accordingly, in South Carolina, â€œthe estate conveyed by the deed must be determined from the whole deed including the
habendum clause.â€Â  Batesburg-Leesville Sch. Dist. No. 3 v. Tarrant, 293 S.C. 442, 445, 361 S.E.2d 343, 345 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Luculently, the habendum clause in the Deed is the section beginning â€œTO HAVE AND TO HOLD . . .â€Â  
The habendum clause in the Deed is followed by Crescentâ€™s covenant to Bristol whereby Crescent â€œcovenants to warrant specially the title to the Property against the lawful claims of any person claiming from, through, or under it.â€Â  â€œThe doctrine of caveat emptor . . . has, in the absence of fraud and misrepresentation long governed the obligations of the parties in the sale of real estate in this State.â€Â  Rutledge v. Dodenhoff, 254 S.C. 407, 412, 175 S.E.2d 792, 794 (1970).Â  In South Carolina, the purchaser of unimproved land must covenant to protect whatever special rights or interests he would presume to acquire in the land.Â  Jackson v. River Pines, Inc., 276 S.C. 29, 31, 274 S.E.2d 912, 913 (1981); see also 21 C.J.S. Covenants Â§ 14 (1990) (â€œThe only protection of title afforded a purchaser of land is in the covenants contained in the deed.â€).Â  
In Martin v. Floyd, 282 S.C. 47, 51, 317 S.E.2d 133, 136 (Ct. App. 1984), this court explained:

A South Carolina general warranty deed embraces all of the following five covenants usually inserted in fee simple conveyances by English conveyors: (1) that the seller is seized in fee; (2) that he has a right to convey; (3) that the purchaser, his heirs and assigns, shall quietly enjoy the land; (4) that the land is free from all encumbrances; and (5) for further assurances.


A grantor seeking to include all the common law covenants of title may use the language in section 27-7-10 of the South Carolina Code to carry out this effect. The statute reads:

The following form or purport of a release shall, to all intents and purposes, be valid and effectual to carry from one person to another or others the fee simple of any land or real estate if it shall be executed in the presence of and be subscribed by two or more credible witnesses:
  
The State of South Carolina.
Know all men by these presents that I, A B, of __________, in the State aforesaid, in consideration of the sum of ___ dollars, to me in hand paid by C D of __________ County, State of __________, the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged, have granted, bargained, sold and released and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said C D all that (here describe the premises), together with all and singular the rights, members, hereditaments and appurtenances to said premises belonging or in any wise incident or appertaining; to have and to hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto said C D, his heirs and assigns, forever. And I do hereby bind myself, my heirs, executors, and administrators, to warrant and forever defend all and singular said premises unto said C D, his heirs and assigns, against myself and my heirs and against every person whomsoever lawfully claiming or to claim the same, or any part thereof.
Witness my hand and seal this ___ day of __________ in the year of our Lord __________ and in the ___ year of the independence of the United States of America. __________ [L.S.]
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-10 (Supp. 2005); see 17 S.C. Jur. Covenants Â§ 32 (Supp. 2005).Â  However, section 27-7-10 does not preclude the grantor from using other language of warranty in a deed. 

Section 27-7-10 shall be so construed as not to oblige any person to insert the clause of warranty or to restrain him from inserting any other clause in conveyances, as may be deemed proper and advisable by the purchaser and seller, or to invalidate the forms formerly in use within this State.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-20 (Supp. 2005).
A â€œspecial warrantyâ€ is â€œ[a] warranty against any personâ€™s claim made by, through, or under the grantor or the grantorâ€™s heirs.â€ Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1581 (7th ed. 1999).Â  The deed at issue in Knotts v. Joiner, 217 S.C. 99, 102, 59 S.E.2d 850, 851 (1950), â€œwas a printed form but the warranty clause was so stricken with pen as to change it from the usual general warranty to a special warranty, that is, against the heirs of the grantor only.â€Â  A quitclaim deed, on the other hand, does not convey the fee, but only the right, title, and interest of the grantor.Â  Martin v. Ragsdale, 71 S.C. 67, 77, 50 S.E. 671, 674 (1905).
C. Incorporation of the Plat
Appellantsâ€™ first contention that the incorporation of the Plat creates a representation or covenant of the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way completely ignores the habendum and warranty clauses in the Deed.
â€œThe question as to the purpose and effect of a reference to a plat in a deed is ordinarily one as to the intention of the parties to be determined from the whole instrument and the circumstances surrounding its execution.â€Â  Lancaster v. Smithco, Inc., 246 S.C. 464, 468, 144 S.E.2d 209, 211 (1965).Â  When a deed describes land as shown on a certain plat, such plat becomes part of the deed for the purpose of showing the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed.Â  Hobonny Club, Inc. v. McEachern, 272 S.C. 392, 397, 252 S.E.2d 133, 136 (1979); Carolina Land Co., Inc. v. Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 105, 217 S.E.2d 16, 19 (1975); see also Holly Hill Lumber Co. v. Grooms, 198 S.C. 118, 135, 16 S.E.2d 816, 823 (1941) (â€œ â€˜As a general rule, when maps, plats, or field notes are referred to in a grant or conveyance they are to be regarded as incorporated into the instrument and are usually held to furnish the true description of the boundaries of the land . . . . â€™ â€) (citation omitted).
In Blue Ridge Realty Co. v. Williamson, 247 S.C. 112, 118, 145 S.E.2d 922, 925 (1965), our Supreme Court stated the general rule that when the owner of land has it subdivided and platted into lots and streets and sells and conveys lots with reference to the plat, he thereby dedicates said streets to the use of such lot owners, their successors in title, and the public.Â  See also Carolina Land Co., 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19.Â  Thus, the purchaser of lots with reference to the plat of the subdivision acquires every easement, privilege and advantage shown upon said plat, including the right to the use of all the streets, near or remote, as laid down on the plat by which the lots are purchased.Â  Blue Ridge, 247 S.C. at 119-20, 145 S.E.2d at 925; Carolina Land Co., 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19.
In Lancaster, 246 S.C. at 469, 144 S.E.2d at 211, â€œ[t]he only reference in the deed in th[e] case to the plat was in connection with the description of the lot.â€Â  Therefore, such reference to the recorded plat made it a part of the deed for the purpose of showing the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed.Â  Id.Â  In that case, our Supreme Court edified:

A plat, however, is not an index to encumbrances, and the mere reference in a deed, as in this case, to a plat for descriptive purposes does not incorporate a notation thereon as to an easement held by a third party so as to exclude such easement from the covenant against encumbrances in the absence of a clear intention that it so operate.

Id.Â  
Both Blue Ridge and Lancaster look to the intention of the parties in incorporating a plat to determine its effect.Â  In the instant case, a reading of the Deed as a whole reveals the parties used the Plat as a reference to the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed.Â  However, Crescent unambiguously put the burden of obtaining an accurate survey on Appellants and excluded from its grant â€œmatters affecting title to the Property as shown on the Plat,â€ matters â€œwhich would be shown on a current and accurate survey of the Property,â€ and rights-of-way of public streets and roads.Â  Moreover, Appellants do not dispute â€œ[t]he actual dimensions and location of a highway right of way are things that will be revealed by a current and accurate survey of the property prepared by the surveyor.â€ The intention of the parties in incorporating the Plat, when discerned from the Deed as a whole, was to show the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed, not to represent or warranty the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way.
D. Failure to Convey 47.82 Acres
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We observe Appellantsâ€™ second contention that Crescent failed to convey 47.82 acres of property directly contravenes well-established law in South Carolina.Â  Appellants essentially claim SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way, an easement, reduces the fee simple grant by the total acreage of the easement.Â  In Douglas v. Med. Investors, Inc., 256 S.C. 440, 445, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1971), respondent contended the reservation of an easement in a deed was â€œrepugnant to the fee simple title granted and is, therefore, ineffective.â€Â  Our Supreme Court noted:

â€˜An easement is a right which one person has to use the land of another for a specific purpose.â€™ Steele v. Williams, 204 S.C. 124, 28 S.E.2d 644; and â€˜gives no title to the land on which the servitude is imposed,â€™ Morris v. Townsend, 253 S.C. 628, 172 S.E.2d 819. An easement is therefore not an estate in lands in the usual sense.â€™

Id.Â  Thus, the court held the easement in that case â€œin no way cut down the fee simple estate conveyedâ€ and, therefore, â€œthe reservation of the easement following
the description in the deed was not repugnant to the fee simple title conveyed in the granting clause.â€Â  Id. at 445-46, 182 S.E.2d at 722.Â  
Reading the Deed as a whole, the granting clause conveyed fee simple title in 47.82 acres of property to Bristol. Therefore, Appellantsâ€™ second argument is without merit.
E. The Habendum Clause
Appellants complain the habendum clause is ambiguous.Â  Exception (6) in the habendum clause provides:

[E]asements, covenants, restrictions and conditions of record, and rights-of-way of public and private streets and roads, including, but not limited to, the road shown on the Plat as â€œold road bedâ€ and the sixty-six (66) foot wide road right-of-way shown on the Plat as â€œSC 188 Keowee School Road (66â€™ R/W)â€ . . . .

(emphasis added).Â  Appellants claim the emphasized language warrants the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way.Â  We agree the emphasized language indicates the parties assumed SCDOTâ€™s right of way was sixty-six feet wide.Â  However, all of the language in exception (6), read with the Deed as a whole, clearly and unambiguously placed the liability of error with respect to the Plat on Bristol and subsequent purchasers.Â  Under no possible construction of the habendum clause can Appellants claim they had a right to rely on the Plat and, if the Plat contained an error, seek damages from Crescent.
F. Limitation on Special Warranty
Appellants argue the special warranty clause in the Deed automatically provides protection against prior encumbrances created by Crescent.Â  To hold otherwise allegedly would render it a quitclaim deed.Â  A special warranty binds the grantor and the grantorâ€™s heirs.Â  See Knotts, 217 S.C. 99, 102, 59 S.E.2d 850, 851 (1950).Â  However, â€œ[t]he grantor can, and often does, limit [covenants] so as to exclude existing encumbrances.â€Â  G.W. Thompson, Thompson on Real Property Â§ 82.10(c)(3) (Supp. 2005); see Â§ 27-7-20; see also Steele v. McRaney, 855 So. 2d 1114, 1122-23 (Ala. Civ. App. 2003) (finding language grantee would take â€œsubject toâ€ matters a survey or inspection of the property would have uncovered prevented grantee from prevailing in breach of deed covenant claim); Kamenar R.R. Salvage, Inc. v. Ohio Edison Co., 607 N.E.2d 1108, 1113 (Ohio Ct. App. 1992) (holding when a deed provides grantee would take subject to â€œthe state of facts which a personal inspection or accurate survey would disclose,â€ grantee has no claim against grantor for power line easement). 
Here, exceptions (5) and (6) in the habendum clause of the Deed limit Crescentâ€™s special warranty to Bristol.Â  Specifically, the exceptions put Bristol and subsequent purchasers on notice Crescent was not covenanting the Plat, matters which would be uncovered by a current and accurate survey, or public rights-of-way.Â  In this respect, Crescent did not covenant the Property would be free from all encumbrances.Â  Instead, in keeping with section 27-7-20, it limited its covenant to those encumbrances not excepted through the habendum clause. The circuit court did not err in finding exceptions (5) and (6) of the habendum clause limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty. 
II. Appellants v. Investors
A. Policy Coverage
Appellants maintain an ownersâ€™ title insurance policy always provides coverage against a surveying error.Â  We disagree.
â€œOwnersâ€™ title insurance policies generally exclude coverage for . . . matters which would be disclosed by an accurate survey and inspection of the premises.â€Â  16 Powell on Real Property Â§ 92.12 (2005); see also Stephen A. Spitz, Real Estate Transactions Cases and Materials 498 (2d ed. 1998) (â€œTitle commitments or policies often include an exception to those matters which a survey and examination of the ground would reveal.â€).Â  In Walker Rogge, Inc. v. Chelsea Title & Guar. Co., 562 A.2d 208, 217 (N.J. 1989), the Supreme Court of New Jersey explained the rationale behind this rule:

The purpose of the survey exception is to exclude coverage when the insured fails to provide the insurer with a survey. From a search of relevant public records, a title company cannot ascertain the risks that an accurate survey would disclose. Â It is for this reason that the title company puts that risk on the insured, who
can control it either by obtaining a survey or arranging for the elimination of the survey exception. Â Thus, the very purpose of a survey exception is to exclude from coverage errors that would be revealed not by a search of public records, but by an accurate survey.

(citation omitted); see also 16 Powell on Real Property Â§ 92-12[1] (2005) (â€œExtended coverage for survey matters is available upon request.Â  The extra coverage is more expensive than standard coverage and may require the purchase of a property survey.â€).Â  
Moreover, a legion of case law recognizes title insurance policies using survey exceptions.Â  See, e.g., Daniel v. Coastal Bonded Title Co., 539 So. 2d 567, 568 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1989); Heyd v. Chicago Title Ins. Co., 354 N.W.2d 154, 155 (Neb. 1984); U.S. Life Title Ins. Co. v. Hutsell, 296 S.E.2d 760, 763 (Ga. Ct. App. 1982); Mims v. Louisville Title Ins. Co., 358 So. 2d 1028, 1028 (Ala. 1978); Nautilus, Inc. v. Transam. Title Ins. Co., 534 P.2d 1388, 1391 (Wash. Ct. App. 1975); Waterview Assocs., Inc. v. Lawyers Title Ins. Corp., 186 N.W.2d 803, 803-04 (Mich. Ct. App. 1971); Kuhlman v. Title Ins. Co., 177 F. Supp. 925, 926 (W.D. Mo. 1959).[5]
B. Title Commitment
Appellants assert that Investorsâ€™ failure to put a survey exception in the title commitment rendered the survey exception in the Policy invalid.Â  Appellants did not preserve this issue for our review.Â  The circuit court did not rule on this issue, and Appellants did not seek a ruling on it in their Rule 59, SCRCP, motion.Â  See Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 235, 612 S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.â€); McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 381, 597 S.E.2d 181, 186 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
Additionally, Appellants fail to cite any case law for this proposition and make only conclusory arguments in support thereof.Â  Thus, Appellants abandoned this issue on appeal.Â  See Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608 S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting when an appellant fails to cite any supporting authority for his position and makes conclusory arguments, the appellant abandons the issue on appeal).Â  Consequently, we decline to address this issue.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s summary judgment order. Crescent did not represent or covenant the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way by incorporating the Plat.Â  Moreover, Crescent coveyed 47.82 acres of real property to Bristol.Â  The habendum clause unambiguously places the burden of a survey defect on Bristol and subsequent purchasers, and the circuit court correctly held exceptions (5) and (6) of the habendum clause limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.
We decline to hold a title insurance policy always insures against surveying errors. Appellants failed to preserve the issue of whether the commitment precluded Investors from including the survey exception to the Policy.Â  Alternatively, Appellants offered only conclusory arguments to support this contention on appeal and, therefore, abandoned that argument.Â  
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J. and SHORT, J., concur.

[1] Investors later referred to this commitment as one made to Appellants.Â  Appellants deeded the Property to Executive on June 10, 2002.Â  During a hearing, Appellantsâ€™ attorney indicated they had formed Executive â€œfor the purposes of developing the Property.â€Â  Executive is not a party to the circuit court proceedings or this appeal.
[2] Crescent Resources, LLC conveyed the Property to Bristol. The Deed indicates Crescent Resources, LLC is â€œa successor by merger and conversion to Crescent Resources, Inc., whose name was changed from Crescent Land and Timber Corp.â€Â  Crescent Land and Timber Corp. granted the easement to SCDOT.Â Â  
[3] Although our case caption lists CBS and Bristol as Respondents, the record does not include any pleadings, motions, or orders from these parties, except the transcript of a motion to compel heard by the circuit court.Â  CBS and Bristol did not submit briefs on appeal and were not parties to the circuit courtâ€™s orders.Â  Additionally, the record does not disclose the procedural position of either party at the time of this appeal.
[4] Investors separately appealed the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Crescent.Â  See Court of Appeals Docket No. 14360, Bennett v. Investors (2).
[5] For further edification, we note Appellants do not contend the loss here arose from a surveying error discoverable through the public records.Â  However, the parties do not dispute SCDOT recorded its right-of-way.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-550 (2006) (directing all rights-of-way for state highways be filed at SCDOT).Â  Furthermore, we recognize â€œ[t]he survey exception is aimed at excluding from coverage certain risks that can be ascertained by a physical inspection of the property.â€Â  G.W. Thompson, Thompson on Real Property Â§ 93.06(c) (2002) (emphasis added). Our Supreme Court, in Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000), provided:

An appellate court may not, of course, reverse for any reason appearing in
the record. Â The losing party must first try to convince the lower court it has ruled wrongly and then, if that effort fails, convince the appellate court that the lower court erred. Â This principle underlies the long-established preservation requirement that the losing party generally must both present his issues and arguments to the lower court and obtain a ruling before an appellate court will review those issues and arguments.

(emphasis in original).Â  Accordingly, we refuse to apply a rule of law Appellants failed to point out to this court or the circuit court.

title: Bennett v. Investors Title Insurance Company
description: In this civil action, the Circuit Judge granted summary judgment in regard to the claims of Investors Title Insurance Company against Crescent Resources, LLC.  The issues on appeal are:  (1)  The Circuit Court erred in concluding the â€œexceptions and exclusionsâ€ in the Crescent Deed precluded deed warranty liability on the part of Crescent; (2) The Circuit Court erred in ruling that the â€œexceptions and exclusionsâ€ in the Crescent Deed precluded deed warranty liability because the habendum clause could not reduce the effect of the granting clause; and (3) The Circuit Court erred in failing to conclude there was an ambiguity in the Crescent Deed in regard to the limited warranty.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kenneth E. Bennett, Richard K. Bennett, James M.
Hendershot, and Robert N. Parker, III, Plaintiffs, 
v.
Investors Title Insurance Company, Defendant. 
      
    
  


 

  
    
      
         Investors Title Insurance Company,
        Appellant,
v.
Crescent Resources, LLC; Bristol, LLC and CBS Surveying & Mapping,
Inc., Defendants,
Of Whom Crescent Resources, LLC is the Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4153
Heard September 9, 2006 â€“ Filed September 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Louis H. Lang, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Benjamin A. Johnson and Stephen A. Cox, both of Rock Hill, and V. Clark Price, of Greenville for Respondent. 
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: In this indemnification action, Investors Title Insurance Â Â Â Company appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Crescent Resources, LLC.Â  On appeal, Investors argues the circuit court erred in failing to hold Crescent liable for an alleged breach of a deed covenant.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 28, 2001, Crescent conveyed 47.82 acres of real property in Oconee County (the Property) to Bristol, LLC, for $2.5 million.Â  The deed from Crescent to Bristol (the Deed), entitled â€œSpecial Warranty Deed,â€ contains a granting clause referring to an attached property description, which, in turn, incorporates a plat (the Plat).Â  CBS Surveying and Mapping, Inc., prepared the Plat for Crescent.Â  The Plat shows a sixty-six foot right-of-way, entitled â€œSC 188 KEOWEE SCHOOL RD (66â€™ R/W),â€ on the western boundary of the Property.Â  
The habendum clause of the Deed reads, in pertinent part:

TO HAVE AND TO HOLD all and singular the Property, unto the said Grantee and Granteeâ€™s heirs, successors and assigns forever, except:
  
Â . . . .
(5) matters affecting title to the Property as shown on the Plat or which would be shown on a current and accurate survey of the Property (including any encroachments);
(6) easements, covenants, restrictions and conditions of record, and rights-of-way of public and private streets and roads, including, but not limited to, the road shown on the Plat as â€œold road bedâ€ and the sixty-six (66) foot wide road right-of-way shown on the Plat as â€œSC 188 Keowee School Road (66â€™ R/W)â€ . . . .
  

The Deed further provides Crescent â€œcovenants to warrant specially the title to the Property against the lawful claims of any person claiming from, through, or under it.â€Â  
Later on the same day, Bristol conveyed the Property by general warranty deed to Kenneth E. Bennett, Richard K. Bennett, James M. Hendershot, and Robert N. Parker, III, (collectively Plaintiffs), for $2.85 million.Â  On January 4, 2002, Plaintiffs procured from Investors an ownerâ€™s title insurance policy (the Policy) covering the Property.Â Â  
Plaintiffs developed the Property and built two brick walls at the entrance near Highway 188. The South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) notified Plaintiffs the walls had been built within SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way.Â  The right-of-way easement, dated August 1, 1968, and recorded at SCDOT, shows Crescent granted a 200 foot right-of-way for Highway 188 to SCDOT.[1]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-550 (2006) (directing all rights-of-way for state highways be filed at
SCDOT).   
After Plaintiffs notified Investors of a possible title insurance claim, Investors offered Plaintiffs $64,000 to settle the claim.Â  Plaintiffs accepted the $64,000 in settlement of its claim for actual damages, leaving a claim for consequential damages outstanding.Â  Having failed to fully settle the claim, Plaintiffs filed a complaint against Investors on June 26, 2003, alleging breach of the title insurance contract and bad faith.Â  Investors answered the complaint and later filed an amended answer, adding a third-party complaint against Crescent, Bristol, and CBS.Â Â  
In its third-party complaint, Investors sought indemnity from Crescent, alleging it breached the special warranty clause in the Deed.Â  Moreover, Plaintiffs later amended their complaint to allege a breach of the Deedâ€™s warranty clause by Crescent and Bristol and negligence by CBS.Â  Crescent filed separate answers to Investorsâ€™ third-party complaint and Plaintiffsâ€™ amended complaint.Â Â Â Â  
Investors moved for summary judgment against Plaintiffs. Subsequently, Crescent moved for summary judgment against Investors and Plaintiffs.[2]Â  The circuit court granted Crescentâ€™s motion for summary judgment against both Plaintiffs and Investors, holding exceptions (5) and (6) in the habendum clause of the Deed limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.Â  Furthermore, the circuit court applied its ruling to Investors, finding Investors could not recover more than Plaintiffs.Â  
Investors moved to alter or amend this order.Â  The circuit court denied this motion but made minor factual corrections and entered an amended order.Â  The circuit court also granted summary judgment to Investors against Plaintiffs.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006); Miller v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 219, 616 S.E.2d 722, 729 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006); Eagle Container Co., LLCÂ  v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 620, 622 S.E.2d 733, 737 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go the jury. Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.E.2d 588, 595, 608 S.E.2d 587, 591 (Ct. App. 2005). Summary judgment is appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Law, 323 S.C. at 434, 629 S.E.2d at 648; BPS, Inc. v. Worthy, 362 S.C. 319, 325, 608 S.E.2d 155, 159 (Ct.App.2005). On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below. Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 25, 630 S.E.2d 474, 477 (2006); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 317, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct.App.2003) (stating that all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law. Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Miller, 365 S.C. at 220, 616 S.E.2d at 729; Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 608 S.E.2d 440 (Ct. App. 2004). Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied. Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct.App.2004). However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted. Rife v. Hitachi Const. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 214, 609 S.E.2d 565, 568 (Ct. App. 2005); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004). 
The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact. Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 228, 612 S.E.2d 719, 722 (Ct. App. 2005). The moving party may discharge the burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact by pointing out the absence of evidence to support the nonmoving partyâ€™s case. Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.E. 256, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002). Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings. Wogan v. Kunze, 366, S.C. 583, 591, 623, S.E.2d 107, 112 (Ct. App. 2005). The nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial. Rife, 363 S.C. at 214, 609 S.E.2d at 568.
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder. Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); Eagle Container, 366 S.C. at 621, 622 S.E.2d at 738; Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 393, 593 S.E.2d 183, 186 (Ct.App.2004). Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues. Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 644, 594 S.E.2d 455, 462 (2004); Wogan, 366, S.C. at 592, 623, S.E.2d at 112; B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Investors contends the circuit court erred in holding exceptions (5) and (6) in the habendum clause of the Deed limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.Â  Investors argues: (1) the granting clause and its incorporation of the Plat created a representation or covenant of the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way; Â (2) exceptions (5) and (6) in the Deedâ€™s habendum â€œcuts downâ€ the fee simple estate conveyed in the granting clause, rendering the habendum Â repugnant to the granting clause; (3) the habendum and granting clause are inconsistent, making the Deed ambiguous; and (4) the Deedâ€™s special warranty automatically protects Bristol and subsequent purchasers against claims created by Crescent; otherwise, the Deed would be a quitclaim deed.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Construction of the Deed
The construction of a clear and unambiguous deed is a question of
law for the court.Â  Hammond v. Lindsay, 277 S.C. 182, 184, 284 S.E.2d 581, 582 (1981); Hunt v. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 568, 595 S.E.2d 846, 848 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Vause v. Mikell, 290 S.C. 65, 68, 348 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œThe construction of an unambiguous deed is a question of law, not fact.â€).Â  â€œ â€˜[I]t is the duty of the court to construe deeds and determine their legal effect, where there is no such ambiguity as requires parol proof and submission to the jury.â€™ â€Â  Hunt, 358 S.C. at 569, 595 S.E.2d at 848 (quoting 26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 168 (2001)).
â€œOne of the first canons of construction of a deed is that the intention of the grantor must be ascertained and effectuated if no settled rule of law is contravened.â€Â  S. Ry. Co. v. Smoak, 243 S.C. 331, 336, 133 S.E.2d 806, 808 (1963); Wayburn v. Smith, 270 S.C. 38, 41, 239 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1977); Estate of Sherman, 359 S.C. at 413, 597 S.E.2d at 853; see also McDaniel v. Connor, 206 S.C. 96, 100, 33 S.E.2d 75, 76 (1945) (â€œAs has many times been said, the governing principle in the construction of deeds is that the intention of the grantor, if consistent with law, shall govern.â€).Â  Moreover, in ascertaining such intention the deed must be construed as a whole, and effect given to every part thereof, if such can be done consistently with law.Â  Wayburn, 270 S.C. at 42, 239 S.E.2d at 892; Bean v. Bean, 253 S.C. 340, 343, 170 S.E.2d 654, 655 (1969); Alexander v. Burnet, 39 S.C.L. (5 Rich.) 189, 196 (1851); see also First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia v. Ford, 177 S.C. 40, 46, 180 S.E. 562, 565 (1935) (â€œLarger and more sensible rules of construction require that the whole deed should be considered together, and effect be given to every part, if all can stand together consistently with law . . . . â€).
II. The Deedâ€™s Clauses
Initially, we address the legal effect of the clauses in the Deed.Â  The term â€œpremisesâ€ is used to refer to â€œall that part of [a] deed preceding the habendum clause, containing generally the names or description of the parties; explanatory recitals, including consideration and its receipt; a description of the realty; the exception, if any; and sometimes a designation of the estate or interest conveyed.â€Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 35 (2001); see also Artis v. Artis, 47 S.E.2d 228, 232 (N.C. 1948) (â€œOrdinarily the premises and granting clauses designate the grantee and the thing granted, while the habendum clause relates to the quantum of the estate.â€).Â  
In South Carolina, the term â€œgranting clauseâ€ is used.Â  This court, in Hunt v. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 566-67, 595 S.E.2d 846, 847 (Ct. App. 2004), referred to the following language in a deed as the â€œgranting clause:â€

The First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia . . . [has] granted, bargained, sold and released, and by these presents [does] grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said
[SCFC] and their successors in office all that certain piece . . . .

(emphasis removed); see also Estate of Sherman ex rel. Maddock v. Estate of Sherman ex rel. Snodgrass, 359 S.C. 407, 409, 597 S.E.2d 850, 850-51 (Ct. App. 2004) (referring to similar language in another deed as the â€œgranting clauseâ€).Â  The granting clause in Crescentâ€™s deed to Bristol incorporates an attached property description which, in turn, incorporates the Plat.Â Â  
The Latin phrase â€œhabendum et tenendumâ€ means â€œto have and to hold.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 716 (7th ed. 1999).Â  Thus, in Hunt, 358 S.C. at 567, 595 S.E.2d at 847, this court quoted the habendum clause in that deed:Â  â€œTo Have and to Hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto the said [SCFC] and their successors in office, and assigns forever.â€Â  (emphasis removed); see also Smoak v. McClure, 236 S.C. 548, 549, 115 S.E.2d 55, 55 (1960) (â€œThe
habendum clause is regular in form, as follows:
â€˜To have and to hold, all and singular, the said premises before mentioned unto the said Ben Garris, and his Heirs and Assigns forever.â€™ â€).Â  
The habendum â€œis the clause usually following the granting part of the premises of a deed, which defines the extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the grantee.â€ 26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 36 (2001).Â  Accordingly, in South Carolina, â€œthe estate conveyed by the deed must be determined from the whole deed including the
habendum clause.â€Â  Batesburg-Leesville Sch. Dist. No. 3 v. Tarrant, 293 S.C. 442, 445, 361 S.E.2d 343, 345 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Luculently, the habendum in the Deed is the section beginning â€œTO HAVE AND TO HOLD . . .â€ 
The habendum in the Deed to Bristol is followed by Crescentâ€™s covenant to Bristol whereby Crescent â€œcovenants to warrant specially the title to the Property against the lawful claims of any person claiming from, through, or under it.â€Â  â€œThe doctrine of caveat emptor . . . has, in the absence of fraud and misrepresentation long governed the obligations of the parties in the sale of real estate in this State.â€ Rutledge v. Dodenhoff, 254 S.C. 407, 412, 175 S.E.2d 792, 794 (1970).Â  In South Carolina, the purchaser of unimproved land must covenant to protect whatever special rights or interests he presumes to acquire in the land.Â  Jackson v. River Pines, Inc., 276 S.C. 29, 31, 274 S.E.2d 912, 913 (1981); see also 21 C.J.S. Covenants Â§ 14 (1990) (â€œThe only protection of title afforded a purchaser of land is in the covenants contained in the deed.â€).Â  
In Martin v. Floyd, 282 S.C. 47, 51, 317 S.E.2d 133, 136 (Ct. App. 1984), this court explained:

A South Carolina general warranty deed embraces all of the following five covenants usually inserted in fee simple conveyances by English conveyors: (1) that the seller is seized in fee; (2) that he has a right to convey; (3) that the purchaser, his heirs and assigns, shall quietly enjoy the land; (4) that the land is free from all encumbrances; and (5) for further assurances.


A grantor seeking to include all of the common law covenants of title may use the language in section 27-7-10 of the South Carolina Code to carry out this effect. The statute reads:

The following form or purport of a release shall, to all intents and purposes, be valid and effectual to carry from one person to another or others the fee simple of any land or real estate if it shall be executed in the presence of and be subscribed by two or more credible witnesses:
  
The State of South Carolina.
Know all men by these presents that I, A B, of __________, in the State aforesaid, in consideration of the sum of ___ dollars, to me in hand paid by C D of __________ County, State of __________, the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged, have granted, bargained, sold and released and by these presents do grant, bargain, sell and release unto the said C D all that (here describe the premises), together with all and singular the rights, members, hereditaments and appurtenances to said premises belonging or in any wise incident or appertaining; to have and to hold all and singular the premises before mentioned unto said C D, his heirs and assigns, forever. And I do hereby bind myself, my heirs, executors, and administrators, to warrant and forever defend all and singular said premises unto said C D, his heirs and assigns, against myself and my heirs and against every person whomsoever lawfully claiming or to claim the same, or any part thereof.
Witness my hand and seal this ___ day of __________ in the year of our Lord __________ and in the ___ year of the independence of the United States of America. __________ [L.S.]
  

S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-10 (Supp. 2005); see 17 S.C. Jur. Covenants Â§ 32 (Supp. 2005).Â  However, section 27-7-10 does not preclude the grantor from using other warranty language in a deed. 

Section 27-7-10 shall be so construed as not to oblige any person to insert the clause of warranty or to restrain him from inserting any other clause in conveyances, as may be deemed proper and advisable by the purchaser and seller, or to invalidate the forms formerly in use within this State.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-20 (Supp. 2005).
A â€œspecial warrantyâ€ is â€œ[a] warranty against any personâ€™s claim made by, through, or under the grantor or the grantorâ€™s heirs.â€ Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1581 (7th ed. 1999).Â  For example, the deed at issue in Knotts v. Joiner, 217 S.C. 99, 102, 59 S.E.2d 850, 851 (1950), â€œwas a printed form but the warranty clause was so stricken with pen as to change it from the usual general warranty to a special warranty, that is, against the heirs of the grantor only.â€Â  A quitclaim deed, on the other hand, does not convey the fee, but only the right, title, and interest of the grantor.Â  Martin v. Ragsdale, 71 S.C. 67, 77, 50 S.E. 671, 674 (1905).
III. Incorporation of the Plat
Investorsâ€™ initial argument that the incorporation of the Plat creates a representation or covenant of the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way completely ignores the habendum and warranty clauses.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Â â€œThe question as to the purpose and effect of a reference to a plat in a deed is ordinarily one as to the intention of the parties to be determined from the whole instrument and the circumstances surrounding its execution.â€Â  Lancaster v. Smithco, Inc., 246 S.C. 464, 468, 144 S.E.2d 209, 211 (1965).Â  When a deed describes land as shown on a certain plat, such plat becomes part of the deed for the purpose of showing the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed.Â  Hobonny Club, Inc. v. McEachern, 272 S.C. 392, 397, 252 S.E.2d 133, 136 (1979); Carolina Land Co., Inc. v. Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 105, 217 S.E.2d 16, 19 (1975); see also Holly Hill Lumber Co. v. Grooms, 198 S.C. 118, 135, 16 S.E.2d 816, 823 (1941) (â€œ â€˜As a general rule, when maps, plats, or field notes are referred to in a grant or conveyance they are to be regarded as incorporated into the instrument and are usually held to furnish the true description of the boundaries of the land . . . . â€™ â€).
In Blue Ridge Realty Co. v. Williamson, 247 S.C. 112, 118, 145 S.E.2d 922, 925 (1965), our Supreme Court stated the general rule that when the owner of land has it subdivided and platted into lots and streets and sells and conveys lots with reference to the plat, he thereby dedicates said streets to the use of such lot owners, their successors in title and the public. See also Carolina Land Co., 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19.Â  Thus, the purchaser of lots with reference to the plat of the subdivision acquired every easement, privilege and advantage shown upon said plat, including the right to the use of all the streets, near or remote, as laid down on the plat by which the lots were purchased.Â  Blue Ridge, 247 S.C. at 119-20, 145 S.E.2d at 925; Carolina Land Co., 265 S.C. at 105, 217 S.E.2d at 19.
In Lancaster, 246 S.C. at 469, 144 S.E.2d at 211, â€œ[t]he only reference in the deed in th[e] case to the plat was in connection with the description of the lot.â€Â  Therefore, such reference to the recorded plat made it a part of the deed for the purpose of showing the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed. Id.Â  In that case, our Supreme Court edified:

A plat, however, is not an index to encumbrances, and the mere reference in a deed, as in this case, to a plat for descriptive purposes does not incorporate a notation thereon as to an easement held by a third party so as to exclude such easement from the covenant against encumbrances in the absence of a clear intention that it so operate.

Id.Â  (emphasis added).
Both Blue Ridge and Lancaster looked to the intention of the parties in incorporating a plat to determine its effect.Â  In the present case, a reading of the Deed as a whole reveals the parties used the Plat as a reference to the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed.Â  Crescent put the burden of obtaining an accurate survey on Plaintiffs and excluded from its grant â€œmatters affecting title to the Property as shown on the Plat,â€ matters â€œwhich would be shown on a current and accurate survey of the Property,â€ and rights-of-way of public streets and roads.Â  Moreover, Investors does not dispute that â€œ[t]he actual dimensions and location of a highway right-of-way are things that will be revealed by a current and accurate survey of the property prepared by the surveyor.â€Â  Accordingly, we hold the intention of the parties in incorporating the Plat, when discerned from the Deed as a whole, was to show the boundaries, metes, courses and distances of the property conveyed, rather than represent or warranty the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way.
IV. The Habendum
Investorsâ€™ second contention that the habendum of the Deed is repugnant to or inconsistent with its granting clause is without merit.Â  We recognize â€œwhen the estates given in the granting clause and the habendum of a deed are so repugnant to each other as not to be susceptible of any reasonable reconciliation, the granting clause will control and the habendum will be rejected as void.â€Â  Glasgow v. Glasgow, 221 S.C. 322, 327, 70 S.E.2d 432, 434 (1952).Â  When the granting clause in a deed purports to convey a fee simple absolute title, subsequent provisions of the deed cannot diminish that granted or deprive the grantee of the incidents of ownership in the property.Â  Shealy v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 278 S.C. 132, 135, 293 S.E.2d 306, 308 (1982).Â  In Porter v. Ingram, 16 S.C.L. (Harp.) 492, 493-94 (1824), the Constitutional Court of Appeals of South Carolina held â€œwhen the premises are complete and perfect and the habendum is at variance with them, and they cannot stand together, the habendum is void.â€Â  See also Rhodes v. Black, 170 S.C. 193, 202, 170 S.E. 158, 161 (1933) (â€œWhere the habendum is repugnant to or irreconcilable with the grant, it will be rejected, and the grant will prevail.â€).
Investors essentially asserts SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way, an easement, reduces the fee simple grant by the total acreage of the easement.Â  This position directly contravenes established law in South Carolina.Â  In Douglas v. Med. Investors, Inc., 256 S.C. 440, 445, 182 S.E.2d 720, 722 (1971), respondent contended the reservation of an easement in a deed was â€œrepugnant to the fee simple title granted and is, therefore, ineffective.â€Â  Our Supreme Court noted:

â€˜An easement is a right which one person has to use the land of another for a specific purpose.â€™ Steele v. Williams, 204 S.C. 124, 28 S.E.2d 644; and â€˜gives no title to the land on which the servitude is imposed,â€™ Morris v. Townsend, 253 S.C. 628, 172 S.E.2d 819. An easement is therefore not an estate in lands in the usual sense.â€™

Id.Â  Thus, the court held the easement in that case â€œin no way cut down the fee simple estate conveyedâ€ and, therefore, â€œthe reservation of the easement following
the description in the deed was not repugnant to the fee simple title conveyed in the granting clause.â€Â  Id. at 445-46, 182 S.E.2d at 722.Â  
Reading the Deed as a whole, the granting clause conveyed fee simple title in 47.82 acres of property to Bristol.Â  The habendum then defines â€œthe extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the grantee.â€Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§ 36 (2001).Â  In the instant case, the habendum is not repugnant to or inconsistent with the granting clause.Â  Therefore, we conclude the habendum is not void, and the Deed is not ambiguous.
V. Limitation of Special Warranty
Investors maintains the special warranty clause in the Deed automatically provides protection against prior encumbrances created by Crescent.Â  To hold otherwise allegedly would render it a quitclaim deed.Â  A special warranty binds the grantor and the grantorâ€™s heirs.Â  See Knotts v. Joiner, 217 S.C. 99, 102, 59 S.E.2d 850, 851 (1950).Â  However, â€œ[t]he grantor can, and often does, limit [covenants] so as to exclude existing encumbrances.â€Â  G.W. Thompson, Thompson on Real Property Â§ 82.10(c)(3) (Supp. 2005); see Â§ 27-7-20; see also Steele v. McRaney, 855 So. 2d 1114, 1122-23 (Ala. Civ. App. 2003) (finding language grantee would take â€œsubject toâ€ matters a survey or inspection of the property would have uncovered prevented grantee from prevailing in breach of deed covenant claim); Kamenar R.R. Salvage, Inc. v. Ohio Edison Co., 607 N.E.2d 1108, 1113 (Ohio Ct. App. 1992) (finding when a deed provides grantee would take subject to â€œthe state of facts which a personal inspection or accurate survey would disclose,â€ grantee has no claim against grantor for power line easement). 
Here, exceptions (5) and (6) in the habendum clause of the Deed limit Crescentâ€™s special warranty to Bristol.Â  Specifically, the exceptions put Bristol and subsequent purchasers on notice Crescent was not covenanting the Plat, matters which would be uncovered by a current and accurate survey, or public rights-of-way. In this respect, Crescent did not covenant the Property would be free from all encumbrances.Â  Instead, in keeping with section 27-7-20, Crescent limited its covenant to encumbrances not excepted through the habendum clause.Â  The circuit court did not err in finding exceptions (5) and (6) of the habendum clause limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty. 
CONCLUSION
We hold Crescent did not represent or covenant the width of SCDOTâ€™s right-of-way by incorporating the Plat.Â  Moreover, the habendum clause in the Deed is not repugnant to or inconsistent with the grant.Â  Concomitantly, the habendum is not void, and the Deed is not ambiguous.Â  The circuit court correctly held exceptions (5) and (6) of the habendum limited Crescentâ€™s special warranty.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J. and SHORT, J., concur.

[1] Crescent Resources, LLC conveyed the Property to Bristol.Â  The Deed indicates Crescent Resources, LLC is â€œa successor by merger and conversion to Crescent Resources, Inc., whose name was changed from Crescent Land and Timber Corp.â€Â  Crescent Land and Timber Corp. granted the easement to SCDOT.Â Â  
[2] This motion is not included in the record.Â Â Â Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Michael J. McEachern, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Employment Security Commission, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Special Referee

Opinion No.Â  4154
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed September 25, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael J. McEachern, of Port Royal, pro se Â Appellant.
Harold W. Funderburk, Jr., of the South Carolina Employment Security Commission, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Michael J. McEachern appeals from a circuit court order affirming the denial of his claim for unemployment benefits by the South Carolina Employment Security Commission (the Commission).Â  We affirm, finding substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s ruling.[1]
FACTS
McEachern began working in 1991 for the Roof Doctor, a business he formed that provides residential and commercial roofing services.[2]Â  McEachern, the president of the corporation, is responsible for providing job proposals and estimates.Â  He is the only person performing that function.Â  His wife, Marilyn Smith, serves as the office manager.Â  
Since 1991, the Roof Doctor has maintained an average of about twelve employees.Â  When business slumped in 2002, the Roof Doctor laid off some employees, keeping a â€œskeleton crewâ€ of about five or six employees, including McEachern, and sold some equipment.Â  Because of the business downturn, McEachern eventually stopped taking a salary altogether.Â  According to Smith, McEachern drew a salary of only $3,367.68 during the second quarter of 2003, compared with more than $11,000.00 for the previous quarter.Â  Further, for the ten weeks immediately prior to the hearing in this matter, McEachern had not drawn a salary so the company could pay some of its outstanding financial obligations.Â  McEachern continued, however, to work at least sixty hours a week, preparing bids and seeking jobs for the company.Â  Business had been picking up, and the Roof Doctor expected to soon be able to resume paying McEachern a salary.Â  McEachern had no plans to close the business or to look for other employment.Â  Â Â 
In June 2003, McEachern filed a claim for unemployment benefits while he continued to work for his company.Â  On June 17, 2003, the Commissionâ€™s Claims Adjudicator found McEachern did not meet the statutory eligibility requirement of being unemployed through no fault of his own because â€œas an officer of a corporation, [he had] control over [his] unemployment benefits.â€Â  McEachern was deemed ineligible for benefits as of June 1, 2003.Â  
On July 17, 2003, the Appeal Tribunal of the Commission upheld the Claims Adjudicatorâ€™s determination.Â  The Tribunal noted section 41-35-110 of the South Carolina Code provides a claimant must have unrestricted exposure to the labor market and be unemployed through no fault of his own.Â  The Tribunal stated:
